title: Under the same roof: The everyday relational practices of contemporary communal living in the UK
abstractText:
This research compares and contrasts four contemporary forms of communal living in the UK, focusing on factors which either contribute to or hinder the attainment of 'successful' communal living across the lifecourse.

Previous research in this area has often focused on intentional communities, such as communes, rather than other forms of co-residence which are both rather more 'ordinary' and, in some cases, much more widespread. Accordingly, this research focuses on shared households, private lodging arrangements, small housing cooperatives, and cohousing projects (resident-controlled developments combining private dwellings with shared facilities), and will explore the intersections of four distinctive aspects of communal living - economic, spatial, temporal and ideological - in each of these contexts.

Qualitative interviews will be conducted with 80 individuals living in communal contexts (20 per type), exploring their housing histories and their current living arrangements. The allocation and use of physical space will be explored using spatial mapping techniques, and three further methods - object inventories, time-use diaries, and network mapping - involving targeted sub-samples of participants will explore the use of 'communal' versus 'private' material resources, the use of shared time in communal contexts, and the impact of living communally on the nature of residentsâ€™ personal networks.
